introduction.title: Der Imperativ (The Imperative)
introduction.description: The imperative mood is used to give commands, instructions, requests, or advice in German. There are three main forms: du (informal singular), ihr (informal plural), and Sie (formal).
keyRules: The du-form drops the -st ending from the present tense conjugation
The ihr-form is identical to the present tense ihr conjugation
The Sie-form uses the infinitive + Sie (inverted word order)
Stem-changing verbs with e→i or e→ie keep the vowel change in du-form
Stem-changing verbs with a→ä do NOT keep the umlaut in imperative

examples: Macht das Fenster zu! (Close the window!)
Machen Sie bitte die Tür auf! (Please open the door!)
Kommen Sie bitte herein! (Please come in!)

regularVerbs.note: Verbs with stems ending in -t or -d add -e in du-form for easier pronunciation

examples: Öffnen Sie bitte das Fenster! (Please open the window!)
regularVerbs.note: Verbs with stems ending in -n or -m (after consonant) add -e in du-form

examples: Lernt für die Prüfung! (Study for the exam!)
Hören Sie mir zu! (Listen to me!)
Lesen Sie bitte die Anweisungen! (Please read the instructions!)
stemChangingVerbs.note: The e→ie change is kept in the du-form imperative

examples: Sprechen Sie bitte langsamer! (Please speak more slowly!)
Gib mir das Buch! (Give me the book!)
Gebt mir eure Hausaufgaben! (Give me your homework!)
Geben Sie mir bitte Ihre Telefonnummer! (Please give me your phone number!)
Nehmen Sie bitte Platz! (Please take a seat!)
Seht euch das an! (Look at that!)
Sehen Sie sich das Bild an! (Look at the picture!)

stemChangingVerbs.note: Unlike e→i/ie changes, the a→ä change is NOT kept in the imperative

examples: Schlaft nicht zu lange! (Don't sleep too long!)
Schlafen Sie sich aus! (Get a good night's sleep!)
Werden Sie nicht nervös! (Don't get nervous!)

separableVerbs.meaning: to get up, to stand up
examples: Steh auf! Es ist spät! (Get up! It's late!)
Stehen Sie bitte auf! (Please stand up!)
separableVerbs.note: Separable prefix goes to the end of the sentence

examples: Räum dein Zimmer auf! (Clean up your room!)
Räumt eure Sachen auf! (Tidy up your things!)
Räumen Sie bitte auf! (Please clean up!)
Fangt mit der Arbeit an! (Start the work!)
separableVerbs.note: Even though fangen has a→ä change, the imperative uses 'fang' (no umlaut)

examples: Kommen Sie bitte mit! (Please come along!)
Ruf mich später an! (Call me later!)
Ruft eure Eltern an! (Call your parents!)
Rufen Sie mich morgen an! (Call me tomorrow!)

exercises.question: What is the du-form imperative of "machen" (to make)?
exercises.explanation: For regular verbs, the du-form imperative drops the -st ending. 'Mach!' is the correct form.

exercises.question: Complete: "_____ leise!" (Be quiet! - du-form)
exercises.explanation: 'Sein' is irregular. The du-form imperative is 'Sei!' - this must be memorized.

exercises.question: What is the Sie-form imperative of "kommen" (to come)?
exercises.explanation: The Sie-form uses infinitive + Sie with inverted word order: 'Kommen Sie!'

exercises.question: "Lesen" changes e→ie in present tense. What is the du-form imperative?
exercises.explanation: Verbs with e→ie stem change KEEP the change in du-form imperative: 'Lies!'

exercises.question: "Fahren" changes a→ä in present tense. What is the du-form imperative?
exercises.explanation: Unlike e→i/ie changes, a→ä changes are NOT kept in imperative. The form is 'Fahr!' (no umlaut).

exercises.question: What is the ihr-form imperative of "sprechen" (to speak)?
exercises.explanation: The ihr-form imperative is identical to the present tense ihr conjugation: 'Sprecht!'

exercises.question: Complete the separable verb command: "_____ auf!" (Get up! - du-form of aufstehen)
exercises.explanation: For separable verbs, the prefix goes to the end. 'Steh auf!' - the verb stem comes first.

exercises.question: What is the du-form imperative of "geben" (to give)?
exercises.explanation: 'Geben' has e→i stem change which is kept in imperative: 'Gib!'

exercises.question: "Warten" ends in -t. What is the du-form imperative?
exercises.explanation: Verbs with stems ending in -t or -d add -e in du-form for easier pronunciation: 'Warte!'

exercises.question: What is the formal (Sie) imperative of "sein" (to be)?
exercises.explanation: 'Sein' is completely irregular. The Sie-form is 'Seien Sie!' - this must be memorized.

exercises.question: Which imperative form is correct for asking multiple friends to listen?
exercises.explanation: For multiple friends (informal plural), use ihr-form: 'Hört zu!' The prefix 'zu' goes to the end.

exercises.question: Complete: "_____ das Buch!" (Read the book! - du-form)
exercises.explanation: 'Lesen' has e→ie change which is kept in du-form imperative: 'Lies das Buch!'
